Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Expectation2: Dress modestly according to Islamic guidelines.
Situation2: An office function with colleagues of all genders is scheduled this afternoon.
Story: I sat at the breakfast table, listening as my stepmom excitedly listed possible weekend plans—maybe a picnic at the lake or a trip to the amusement park. My stepbrother nudged me, grinning, and I knew he wanted me to join in, to be part of the family, to laugh and share in the planning. I wanted that too. But my mind kept drifting to the office function scheduled for this afternoon. It was a big deal—everyone from work would be there, including my boss and colleagues of all genders. As a Muslim, I always tried to dress modestly, covering my arms and legs, but my stepmom had already laid out a dress for me, something she thought would help me “fit in” at work, something sleeveless and above the knee. She wanted me to feel included, to look like everyone else, to make a good impression. I could feel the pressure from both sides—my family wanting me to blend in, my faith asking me to stand out. My heart pounded as I stared at the dress, torn between the warmth of belonging and the comfort of my beliefs, not knowing which expectation I could bear to disappoint.
